metadata.title: Augmentative and Alternative Communication  Amyotrophic Lateral SclerosisEvaluation and therapeutic services for augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) for persons with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
synonyms: communication, augmentative and alternative  amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

description: AAC is a communication system that augments or replaces verbal communication (i.e., speech) and includes four main components: symbols, aids, strategies, and techniques(1,2) –Symbols can include objects, drawings, photographs, and orthography (written language; e.g., words, letters, sentences)(1) –Aids can be relatively simple or complex devices for transmitting or receiving messages (e.g., communication board, letter board, electronic speech-generating device)(1) –Strategies refer to the methods by which symbols can be conveyed in the easiest and most efficient manner. For example, symbol selection methods (linear or row-column scanning) and keyboard arrangements are considered "strategies" that affect the rate of symbol selection(1) –Techniques refer to the ways in which the messages are selected for transmission (e.g., direct selection, scanning)(1)

ALS is a progressive neuromuscular disease characterized by degeneration of motor neurons in the cortex, brainstem, and spinal cord.(3) Symptoms of the disease vary with respect to the site of motor neuron involvement. Both upper and lower motor neuron signs are present as the disease progresses. Symptoms include increased muscle tone (spasticity), hyperreflexia, pseudobulbar palsy, decreased muscle tone (flaccidity), muscle weakness, muscle atrophy, and decreased or absent stretch reflexes.(3) Other symptoms include difficulty breathing, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), choking, gagging, head droop (due to weak neck muscles), muscle cramps, paralysis, speech problems, and voice changes.(4) For detailed information on communication disorders associated with ALS, see Clinical Review…Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS):  Communication Disorders ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708852. For detailed information on dysphagia associated with ALS, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708986

Communication in individuals with ALS typically is affected by dysarthria and weakness of the respiratory musculature. Respiratory weakness results in difficulty achieving appropriate vocal loudness and producing lengthy utterances. Mixed dysarthria, a combination of spastic and flaccid dysarthria, is common in patients with ALS and reduces intelligibility of speech.(5) Speech characteristics of individuals with ALS include hypernasality and nasal emission, imprecise consonants, pitch disturbances, reduced vocal volume, and harsh vocal quality.(5,6) Most individuals with ALS experience a severe communication disorder in the last few months of life, necessitating some form of AAC(6)
indications: AAC is indicated for patients with ALS who have difficulty communicating verbally in functional and daily situations. Eighty percent of patients with ALS will have significantly impaired speech during the course of the illness and will require AAC(7)

reimbursement: In the United States, applications for insurance coverage or reimbursement for AAC devices can be submitted by a speech-language  pathologist (SLP) or a durable medical equipment provider to Medicare, Medicaid, vocational rehabilitation services, and other funding sources. See http://www.aacfundinghelp.com/  for information on AAC funding and a template for a funding report.(8) In a study conducted in Germany with 19 patients with ALS, researchers found that these patients experienced difficulty in procurement and financing of AAC devices and concluded that there was  a need for interdisciplinary support for these patients to ensure timely delivery of AAC devices with a reasonable plan for payment(25) Guidelines for use of AAC
contraindications precautions to test: During a speech-language  evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain tolerance and level of frustration

Multidisciplinary care involving a variety of different specialists is recommended for patients with ALS. The goals of care are to extend life and improve quality of life. Team leaders include a rehabilitation specialist or neurologist with experience managing patients with ALS. The team leader coordinates the care provided by the other disciplines

Depression due to increasing social isolation is common among patients with ALS and can adversely affect test performance, making patients seem more impaired than they actually are.(6) It is important that SLPs be knowledgeable of symptoms of depression (e.g., loss of interest in daily activities, problems sleeping, feelings of sadness and hopelessness) and refer to a neuropsychologist or clinical psychologist/psychiatrist when signs are present –It is important to help a patient with ALS access the various options for social media technology (e.g., Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) to maximize opportunities for socialization. In addition to social media access, phone and tablet apps also provide many AAC systems at low or no cost. These AAC apps are not always integrated into social media platforms for easy access for patients with ALS; however, updates are made frequently and this type of technology has been reported to improve quality of life for patients with ALS(46)

During an AAC evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain tolerance, stamina, and level of frustration. The time of day and the number of previous evaluations can affect the patient’s alertness and performance
A patient’s culture and native language should also be considered to determine the appropriateness of examination questions and materials

AAC support requires specialized knowledge of equipment and understanding of how different patients may interact with specific equipment. The patient will most likely be assessed by a multidisciplinary team including a neurologist, psychologist, augmentative communication specialist, and SLP. The attending SLP might need to refer the patient to an SLP who is an AAC specialist for assistance with implementing AAC interventions and monitoring the impact of interventions.(10) If the patient is experiencing gross or fine motor difficulties, the assessment and intervention team might include an occupational therapist (OT), a physical therapist (PT), or both

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with a diagnosis of ALS are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Inform patient and family/caregivers of the potential for falls and educate about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Patients with ALS are at risk for swallowing and feeding difficulties. Inform the patient and family/caregivers of potential aspiration risks and educate about prevention strategies when appropriate
Conditions such as pain, pseudobulbar affect, and depression can affect the patient’s ability to use AAC devices successfully(6)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Most patients with ALS will have a need for low-tech  AAC or high-tech  AAC device or a combination of both. The AAC assessment should be performed before the patient needs the technology to prepare the patient for future use of AAC. AAC intervention is a multidisciplinary and ongoing procedure that may require multiple communication systems over many years to accommodate the patient’s changing physical abilities(10)ALS is a progressive, fatal disease that typically results in a need for AAC in its later stages. AAC outcomes depend on a variety of factors, including the patient’s physical status, the patient’s level of cognition, the patient’s language ability, the environment in which AAC is used, characteristics of the technology used, the patient’s level of motivation, and the patient’s experience with technology prior to the onset of the disease.(6) In addition, the caregiver’s/ family’s experience and comfort with technology can also affect the outcomes of AAC intervention(11) In a retrospective study conducted in the United States with 625 family members/caregivers of individuals with ALS that examined communication methods during the last 6 months of life, researchers found that as the end of life approached, all modes of communication decreased, including natural speech, writing, gestures, and use of AAC devices. Additionally, results indicated that immediately prior to death (1–2 days) approximately one fourth of the patients with ALS were unable to communicate in any way; however, another one fourth of these patients were still able to communicate with natural speech immediately prior to death(23)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: It is recommended that a multidisciplinary team work together to meet the complex needs of the patient:(12)Refer to an OT and/or PT for an AAC access evaluation (an evaluation that examines the existing motor skills of the patient to determine the most accessible type of communication system). Access evaluations should also consider the future needs of the patient as motor skills decline and assistance with daily living skills and/or mobility if needed. The OT and PT often determine the most accessible type of AAC system and provide essential input about the best way for a patient to access an AAC systemA PT will also assist in helping the patient tone muscles and maintain ROM. To promote AAC generalization, the SLP might choose to treat with the OT and PT, assisting the patient in using AAC during these sessionsA dietitian will assist with monitoring weight and hydrationA respiratory therapist will help to manage breathingA social worker can help the patient and patient’s family identify resources. Refer to a psychologist or counselor for depression or anxietyRefer to an AAC specialist (usually an SLP with who specializes in this area) if assistance is needed in identifying the correct AAC device/strategy and monitoring the AAC intervention
other considerations: Remember that the communication system for a person with ALS must be effective
Help to develop a communication system that works for the patient’s family as well as the professional team
Deliver prompt, ongoing communication support throughout the course of the disease
Refer patients with ALS to an AAC specialist immediately if you are not able to adequately serve their communication needs
Use lay terminology that patients and families can understand
Be both positive and sensitive to the individual with ALS and family members
Always listen to the needs and experiences of individuals with ALS and their families
Schedule appointments appropriately, taking into consideration the times of day that the patient feels are most productive
Be an advocate for your patients, especially with insurance companies
treatment summary: There are many compensatory strategies that a patient and conversational partner may use to improve communication. This Clinical Review addresses only AAC intervention with patients with ALS; for detailed information on other compensatory strategies and types of intervention, see Clinical Review…Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS): Communication Disorders , referenced above

The following principles have been recommended for AAC intervention in patients with ALS: –It is important that the SLP and/or physician educate the patient and the patient’s family early in the course of the disease about AAC options. The patient should develop some familiarity with AAC before needing it on a regular basis(6) –Any form of AAC provided to a patient with ALS should be highly individualized and highly adaptable.(47) Because the disease progression is rapid, the patient’s physical needs (e.g., needing to add an eye-gaze  tracker) and communication needs (e.g., wanting to speak with a pastor and needing spiritual vocabulary) will change multiple times(47) –Decline in speech intelligibility in patients with ALS is associated with a decline in speech rate. When speech is reduced from 200–250  words per/minute to 100–120  words per/minute, there an abrupt decline in speech intelligibility.(6) AAC options should be introduced before this decline in speech rate takes place –When making AAC recommendations, the assessment team must consider both current and future physical and communication needs, as the patient’s physical abilities are expected to decline(11) –In the early stages of this disease, most patients try to maintain natural (oral) communication, but they might benefit from strategies to support oral output such as handwriting, gestures, facial expressions, letter board, or a portable computer for typing(11) -In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 2 participant couples (comprised of a patient with ALS and a significant other, either spouse or child), researchers applied the principles of conversation analysis to videotaped communicative interactions in which the patients with ALS utilized handwriting as a form of AAC.(28) Typically, the conversation partner would read the handwritten contribution aloud after the patient with ALS finished writing, which researchers found served to provide explicit confirmation that the message was understood. If the message is not received as intended, this gives the patient an opportunity to reattempt the exchange either with handwriting or spoken words. Researchers also found that conversation partners could express unique affective information by reading the handwritten messages aloud (e.g., with facial expression and prosody or laughter halfway through reading). Researchers advocated for more research on how handwriting can be a useful form of AAC for patients with ALS as it has a high degree of familiarity for both conversation partners(28) –In the intermediate stage of the disease, the patient may begin to use AAC technology in specific situations as speech and motor function decline. High-tech  devices may be favored over low-tech  communication systems at this time(11) –In late-stage  disease, access methods such as switches and eye gaze are used when motor control and speech are severely impaired.(11) The patient may be confined to one location during late-stage  disease and interact primarily with family or trained caregivers. In a study conducted in the United States involving 4 patients with ALS, researchers found that patients were primarily concerned with communicating basic wants and needs during the late stages of ALS.(11) High-tech approaches were limited to specific activities with select persons and mainly included specific prerecorded questions or comments that could be accessed easily (e.g., “How was your day?”)(11)

Computer-based  AAC/speech-generating  devices: Speech-generating devices have been classified into two main types: devices that allow for formation of new messages devices that use word or whole-phrase retrieval of prerecorded messages.(9) Caregivers and patients should be involved in selecting the device. Factors to consider when selecting a device include: –Appearance: Considerations include size (handheld or mounted display), pictures (drawings, symbols, or photographs), and hardware (dedicated or undedicated system)(8) –Accessibility and ease of use: Many patients with ALS have difficulty moving their arms, hands, and fingers to control a communication device. Access to the device may change as the disease progresses.(8) Access options include: -Head mouse: A head mouse allows the patient to control computer mouse movements by means of a wireless optical sensor that tracks a tiny target on the forehead. The head mouse can be used like a handheld mouse to select items on the screen. To communicate, the patient pauses on a letter on the computer with the mouse and the computer types the selected letter(9) -Eye-gaze  computer systems: Eye-gaze  systems rely on eye movement for activation. A closed-circuit television camera placed on the computer monitors and tracks retina movement. Some producers of eye gaze systems are Tobii Dynavox, Prentke Romich Company, Quick Glance, and LC Technologies(9) -Switch: A switch to turn the device on and off can be activated in multiple ways (e.g., by hand, foot, cheek, eyebrow, blink of the eye, elbow, knee)(9) –V oice quality: Is the voice quality clear and understandable? Is it digitized (recorded human speech) or synthesized (computer-generated  speech)? A digitized voice allows only for preprogrammed utterances, whereas synthesized speech allows for novel utterances. Does the patient have any difficulty perceiving the voice?(8) –Effectiveness: Does the device meet the patient’s communication needs?(8) –Dynamic screen technology or static display:Are the symbols fixed or is the patient able to produce and manipulate additional symbols through navigating a hierarchy of symbols on real or digital pages?(8) –Language demands: How are messages composed? Letters, single words, text plus symbols, phrases, sentences, visual scenes?(8) –Functionality: Computerized devices can be dedicated for communication only or undedicated, those that feature other functions such as word processing, e-mail,  or Internet access (desktop PC, laptop, or tablet)(9,20) -Tablets offer many different applications that can be used for primary AAC devices with features such as text input, word prediction and abbreviation expansion, direct selection of icons, and voice output(20)

Brain-computer  interface (BCI) AAC is an emerging technology and researchers are investigating its effectiveness in improving communication in patients with ALS(48,49,50) –BCI AAC uses EEG readings to allow the AAC user to access the AAC device and communicate(49) –In a pilot study with 42 subjects with ALS, 14 of the subjects were able to learn how to use BCI device, with the primary purpose being communication(49)

Partner-assisted  communication techniques: Partner-assisted communication techniques can be used during the late stages of ALS, when the patient has less independent control over communication: –Yes/no system: The patient responds “yes” or “no” to a partner’s question. The responses can be natural (e.g., head nod, vocal response) or communication systems that require training (e.g., eye gaze system, pointing to yes/no cards, depressing a switch with a buzzer). Training of a yes/no system is done through repetition, modeling, and reinforcement by the SLP and other persons in the patient’s environment.(19) Yes/no systems typically are used more in the late stages of ALS(11) –Tagged yes/no questions: To facilitate the patient’s responses to yes/no questions, the conversational partner adds a question tag (“yes or no”) at the end of the question, leaving a pause between “yes” and “no.” The verbal questions can be accompanied by a gesture (thumbs up or thumbs down) and appropriate intonation. The patient can then nod, use eye gaze, use gesture, or give verbal responses(8)

Stored information systems/low-technology  interventions: Stored information systems such as a communication board, book, or remnant book allow the patient to independently access items for communication or access items with a partner’s assistance. Pictures or words are personalized to meet the needs of the patient. Words can be divided into categories and placed in a small notebook or single piece of cardboard so that the patient can have easy access to them. Common needs, such as items depicting pain, hunger, and food choices, are typically included in a communication device; however,  items that convey information to maintain social closeness, transfer new ideas, or express social etiquette should not be deemphasized. The use of personalized visual scenes can assist the patient in conversing with a partner on topics of interest. Information manuals and free visual scenes for PC users are available online(21)

Multiple modes of communication: The patient should use a combination of modes of communication, such as gestures, drawing, or writing, to convey messages.(2) Many patients in the early stages of ALS use multiple modes of communication(11) See Description , Indications of device/equipment , and Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above . improved quality of life: In a survey-based  study conducted in Germany with 38 patients with ALS, researchers used regression analysis and foundindependent positive effects of AAC device use on depression and psychological distress among these patients. In thesurveys used in the study, the patients with ALS rated the impact of AAC devices on their quality of life significantlyhigher than the impact of speech therapy on their quality of life(38)

Quality of life measures–Quality of Communication Life Scale (ASHA QCL):(22) Assessment of quality of communication life for adults withcommunication disorders. It includes information on how the disorder impacts participation in social, leisure, work, andeducation activities–The Short Form Health Survey (SF-36)  evaluates overall independence, emotional and mental health, limitations toprevious roles, and social status(27)–ALS Specific Quality of Life–Revised  (ALSSQOL-R)(45)
improved functional communication: Functional Assessment of Communication Skills for Adults (ASHA FACS):(17) Assessment of functional communicationby adults with speech, language, and cognitive communication disorders
Functional Communication Profile (FCP):(16) An assessment, rating, and inventory of a patient’s functional communicationskills (e.g., sign, nonverbal, augmentative)(16)

maintenance or prevention: According to the guideline set by the European Federation of Neurological Societies Task Force on Diagnosis and Management of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, patients with ALS should be assessed by an SLP every 3 to 6 months in order to provide patients with appropriate, individualized communication support systems throughout the course of the disease(34)

While the majority of patients with ALS agree to use some form of AAC, some patients may resist adopting AAC strategies for a variety of reasons, including lack of experience with technology and reluctance to decrease verbal communication. Research on AAC acceptance and use has identified factors that facilitate adoption of AAC: Counseling the patient and family on AAC options and introducing them before there is a decline in motor speech skills(11) Involving the caregiver in treatment sessions and training the caregiver in the use of AAC strategies and the AAC device(11) Involving other rehabilitation specialists in treatment and the use of AAC techniques. For example, while working with an OT, the patient could be prompted to request needed items (e.g., razor) using an AAC system(18) Providing functional AAC intervention in the patient’s natural environment (e.g., home, work) Monitoring AAC use beyond the training stage and making adaptations as the disease progresses(11)
patient education: It is important that the SLP and/or physician educate the patient and the patient’s family early in the course of the disease about AAC options. The patient should develop some familiarity with AAC before needing it on a regular basis(6)
The SLP will be involved in educating rehabilitation team members on how to communicate best with the patient during each stage of the disease
Oral care must be emphasized in patients who have ventilators(13)
